title: Do the Greeks want to restore Byzantium? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hell no! Why would we want that? Don’t we have enough problems already? Not to mention that very few Greek people now live in former Byzantine lands. So, why conquer lands of foreign people? Imagine us trying to obey the same rules with Turkish, Balcanian and Middle Eastern people. Imagine Syrian Civil war happening inside our lands. In other words, even if we were a part of a modern Byzantium many of us would be willing to fight so as to separate from it. Oh yes, of course, there are some extreme nationalists. There always are. Not only in Greece, but everywhere. And they entertain us all, forgetful as they are, of the fact the nightmares of global world domination by occupying lands ended with the death of Adolf Hitler. Unaware that there is no positive correlation of the land size of a country and the well being of its citizens. Quite the opposite, actually. There are also few people who want to see Agia Sofia an orthodox church, again. Hilarious. Fortunately, most of us avoid visiting even the orthodox church around the corner, at all costs, probably out of fear of death from extreme boredom. There used to be more, though. Megali idea and stuff. Which, ironically, meant “great idea”. The “great” adjective referring to Greece land area, not the idea itself, which was not so great after all, considering that many of the politicians who had it got an appointment with the hangman and hundreds of thousands of Greek people died, or lost their homes to war because of it.

This ideal was applied in foreign policy as recently as… a century ago. The Megale Idea was a nationalistic (e.g. not much to do with the notion of an imperial state) obsession that spectacularly crashed with the destructive affair of the Greco-Turkish war that flared after WW1. The symbolism of a Byzantine restoration of some sort accompanied what was a far cry from an imperialist campaign. A far cry in the sense that it lacked sound logistics, to say the least. Soon enough, the notion of a claim to the Byzantine territories became moot. However, it has since found at times a sympathetic audience among Greeks. But never more than an unrealistic fantasy, the likes of which official education systems around the world like to shovel into children's minds.

In my opinion, of course it will be something great if it happened, there are few ambitions or dreams behind our head, but no one pushes or acts for this to happen as in we don’t actually care that much, we are happy as we are right now. on the other hand, you cannot just restore Byzantium as it was. We live in a modern era right now and peoples mentality have changed within the centuries. As I said it would be nice if it happened, but we don’t chase it to happen, it is way too far in the long run.

Yes. Totally, with Jesus Christ instead of the Emperor. In fact, the problem in Byzantium was that the Roman Emperor was an actor who personnified Jesus. So he was in a total neurosis, because on one hand he acted as a bloody emperor and on the other hand he sinned. Then he took his own sin as a kind of cross. That was the system, and that system has been brilliantly and tragially exposed by Eisenstein in his Ivan.

No, we don’t. That era is past gone, and to tell the truth, from a scientist’s point of view, not very positive or productive. One has also to to be realistic here. We can’t even support ourselves without constant support and financial aid, how the hell would we go about restoring Byzantium?

Adolf, are you still at large? Well, nope, the Greeks do not want to restore the multinational Eastern Roman Empire - we have far too many illegal immigrants (and a few refugees) from a great variety of nations as it is - we really can’t accept more.

As a fantasy absolutely. At most a restoration of historical places (or churches, buildings, etc) would be more along the lines of what Greeks would want (like the ability to have Divine Liturgy in Hagia Sophia again). As far as an actual empire those days and dreams are long gone.
…sure, we absolutely want to restore the eastern roman empire. Of course not! What kind of idiotic question is this?!

Not that I’m aware of. So many centuries have passed that I’m quite sure that no one basically cares. But what I’m quite sure about is that lots of Greeks who are old(regarding their age) want Cyprus to be restored.
greeks are byzantium . it is restored not fully, our capital and eastern provinces arent free western part is free :)

Most of us don’t care much about Byzantium (Eastern Roman Empire). It was a place of religious fanaticism, corruption, intrigue, violence, with no contribution to the arts (other than religious hymns), literature or the sciences.
Not because the Greeks are not Romans.
